elephants.name: Abul-Abbas
elephants.note: An elephant given to Carolingian emperor Charlemagne by the Abbasid caliph Harun al-Rashid.

elephants.name: Arjuna
elephants.note: A lead elephant of the world-famous Mysore Dasara procession.

elephants.name: Balarama
elephants.note: A lead elephant of the world-famous Mysore Dasara procession.

elephants.name: Black Diamond
elephants.note: Believed to be the largest Indian elephant in captivity.

elephants.name: Batyr
elephants.note: An elephant claimed to be able to use a large amount of meaningful human speech, reported as having a vocabulary of more than 20 phrases.

elephants.name: Chunee
elephants.note: An elephant in the menagerie at Exeter Exchange, executed by soldiers from Somerset House in March 1826.

elephants.name: Chengalloor Ranganathan
elephants.note: Considered the tallest Asian thatever lived. He was killed by another elephant during Arattupuzha Festival in 1927. The century-old skeleton of this elephant is exhibited in the Thrissur Museum in the Main Entrance hall.

elephants.name: The Cremona Elephant
elephants.note: A gift presented to Holy Roman Emperor Frederick II by Sultan of Egypt Al-Kamil, in 1229. Frederick used the elephant in his triumph parades.

elephants.name: Hanno
elephants.note: The pet white elephant given by King Manuel I of Portugal to Pope Leo X at his coronation.

elephants.name: Fanny
elephants.note: A female elephant who spent the majority of her life in a small zoo.

elephants.name: Hansken
elephants.note: A female elephant that became famous in early 17th-century Europe. She toured many countries, demonstrating circus tricks, and was sketched by Rembrandt and Stefano della Bella.

elephants.name: Hattie
elephants.note: An elephant in New York City's Central Park Zoo that was described as the "most intelligent of all elephants" and "nearly human."

elephants.name: Isilo
elephants.note: One of South Africaâ€™s largest Africans and the largest living tusker (a male elephant with tusks weighing over 100 pounds) in the southern hemisphere before his death.

elephants.name: John L. Sullivan
elephants.note: A boxing elephant in Adam Forepaugh's circus.

elephants.name: Echo
elephants.note: Most studied elephant in the world.

elephants.name: Kashin
elephants.note: Famous for being sponsored by ASB Bank, and featured in the New Zealand produced television programme The Zoo.

elephants.name: Jumbo
elephants.note: A 19th-century male African bush elephant born in Sudan. Jumbo was exported to Jardin des Plantes, a zoo in Paris, and then transferred in 1865 to London Zoo in England. Despite public protest, Jumbo was sold to P. T. Barnum, who took him to the United States for exhibition in March 1882.

elephants.name: Kesavan
elephants.note: Perhaps the most famous and celebrated temple elephant in Kerala, India. Keshavan was donated to the Guruvayur Hindu temple by the royal family of Nilambu.

elephants.name: Kolakolli
elephants.note: An Indian rogue elephant which gained considerable notoriety among Indian media and was accused of killing 12 people in and around Peppara over a span of seven to eight years.

elephants.name: Lallah Rookh
elephants.note: A female elephant known for her tightrope walking act.
